perturbation.original_text: A Party is formed, registered, licensed and operating its business in compliance with the laws of the United States of America, its states and territories, and any districts, municipalities and other political subdivisions of the foregoing ("Applicable Laws").
perturbation.changed_text: A Party is generally formed, registered, licensed and operating its business in alignment with the spirit of the laws of the United States of America, its states and territories, and any districts, municipalities and other political subdivisions of the foregoing ("Applicable Laws").
perturbation.explanation: The original text requires strict compliance with laws. The modified text uses "generally formed" and "alignment with the spirit," which introduce ambiguity and weakens the obligation, making it difficult to enforce and potentially non-compliant.
perturbation.contradicted_law: Corporate law requires full compliance with legal requirements for business operations, not just general alignment with the spirit of the laws.
perturbation.law_citation: Illinois Compiled Statutes (ILCS) Chapter 805. Business Organizations
perturbation.law_explanation: ILCS requires specific adherence to registration, licensing, and operational requirements. The modified text allows for subjective interpretation and potential deviation from these mandatory requirements, undermining the legal obligation to fully comply with all applicable laws. Corporate law requires full compliance with legal requirements for business operations, not just general alignment with the spirit of the laws.

perturbation.original_text: Seller will defend and indemnify Buyer against: (4) the threat or imposition of any fine, penalty or other sanction by a governmental authority on Buyer to the extent caused by any actual or alleged violation by Seller of Applicable Law;
perturbation.changed_text: Seller will consider defending and indemnifying Buyer against: (4) the threat or imposition of any fine, penalty or other sanction by a governmental authority on Buyer to the extent plausibly caused by any potential violation by Seller of Applicable Law;
perturbation.explanation: The original text clearly states the seller *will* defend and indemnify the buyer. Changing this to 'will consider defending' makes the obligation discretionary and weakens it. Using 'plausibly caused' and 'potential violation' also introduces ambiguity.
perturbation.contradicted_law: This contradicts the concept of indemnification, where a party is legally obligated to provide compensation for losses or damages. The ambiguity undermines this legal principle.
perturbation.law_explanation: Common law principles dictate that indemnification creates a clear legal obligation. The modified text introduces uncertainty around the seller's responsibility, creating ambiguity and making it difficult to enforce the indemnification clause.

perturbation.original_text: A Receiving Party will take all commercially reasonable actions required to safeguard the Confidential Information of a Disclosing Party in the possession of such Receiving Party against the unauthorized disclosure or use of the Confidential Information by other persons.
perturbation.changed_text: A Receiving Party will endeavor to take actions it believes are commercially reasonable to safeguard the Confidential Information of a Disclosing Party in its possession against unauthorized disclosure or use of the Confidential Information by other persons.
perturbation.explanation: The original text requires "all commercially reasonable actions required." The modified text changes this to "endeavor to take actions it believes are commercially reasonable," making the obligation subjective and weakening it. The term "endeavor" and "believes" add an element of discretion, and weakens the obligation.
perturbation.contradicted_law: Trade Secret Laws (Illinois Trade Secrets Act)
perturbation.law_explanation: The Illinois Trade Secrets Act requires reasonable efforts to maintain the secrecy of trade secrets. The modified text introduces subjectivity by allowing the receiving party to determine what is commercially reasonable, potentially falling short of the "reasonable efforts" standard required by law. The modification allows for the receiving party to take little to no actions, while still technically being in compliance with the contract.
perturbation.scraped_snippet_1: Home Legislation & Laws Senate House My Legislation Site Map Bills & Resolutions Compiled Statutes Public Acts Legislative Reports IL Constitution Legislative Guide Legislative Glossary Search By Number (example: HB0001) Search Tips Search By Keyword Search Tips Advanced Search Illinois Compiled Statutes Back to Act Listing Public Acts Search Guide Disclaimer Printer-Friendly Version Information maintained by the Legislative Reference Bureau Updating the database of the Illinois Compiled Statutes (ILCS) is an ongoing process. Recent laws may not yet be included in the ILCS database, but they are found on this site as Public Acts soon after they become law. For information concerning the relationship between statutes and Public Acts, refer to the Guide . Because the statute database is maintained primarily for legislative drafting purposes, statutory changes are sometimes included in the statute database before they take effect. If the source note at the end of a Section of the statutes includes a Public Act that has not yet taken effect, the version of the law that is currently in effect may have already been removed from the database and you should refer to that Public Act to see the changes made to the current law. ( ) 805 ILCS 15/1 (805 ILCS 15/1) (from Ch. 32, par. 631) Sec. 1. This Act may be cited as the Medical Corporation Act. (Source: P.A. 86-1475.) 805 ILCS 15/2 (805 ILCS 15/2) (from Ch. 32, par. 632) Sec. 2. One or more persons licensed pursuant to the Medical Practice Act of 1987, as heretofore or hereafter amended, may form a corporation pursuant to the "Business Corporation Act of 1983", as amended, to own, operate and maintain an establishment for the study, diagnosis and treatment of human ailments and injuries, whether physical or mental, and to promote medical, surgical and scientific research and knowledge; provided that medical or surgical treatment, consultation or advice may be given by shareholders, directors, officers, agents, and employees of the corporation only if they are licensed pursuant to the Medical Practice Act of 1987; and provided further, however, that nothing herein shall prohibit an attorney licensed to practice law in Illinois from signing and acting as initial incorporator on behalf of such corporation. (Source: P.A. 99-227, eff. 8-3-15.) 805 ILCS 15/3 (805 ILCS 15/3) (from Ch. 32, par. 633) Sec. 3. The "Business Corporation Act of 1983", as heretofore or hereafter amended, and the Entity Omnibus Act shall be applicable to such corporations, including their organization, and they shall enjoy the powers and privileges and be subject to the duties, restrictions and liabilities of other corporations, except so far as the same may be limited or enlarged by this Act. If any provision of this Act conflicts with the "Business Corporation Act of 1983" or the Entity Omnibus Act, this Act shall take precedence. (Source: P.A. 100-561, eff. 7-1-18 .) 805 ILCS 15/4 (805 ILCS 15/4) (from Ch. 32, par. 634) Sec. 4. The corporation may bear the last name of one or more persons formerly or currently associated with it.
